text: good morning to everybody good afternoon
from
Dubai uh I'm delighted to speak to you
um Spangler looks great actually from
this Vantage Point uh last time I was
there um I was there actually to attend
the graduation of my husband uh from
HBS and um I'm absolutely delighted that
I can now say to him you may have gone
to HBS as a student but I was invited to
speak there so thank you so much for
promoting gender equality in my home um
but more importantly really thank you to
Robin and Amy two women whose work that
I really admire for giving me the
opportunity to connect with such a great
group of Scholars and practitioners even
though I wasn't able to attend in
person my virtual participation is
actually apt given the title of our pan
virtual collaborations are key at the
moment uh in higher education
institutions in the US as they go Global
the rise of mukes or massive open online
courses which broadcast us-based
teaching to millions of students
virtually around the world uh the
increase in crossb teaching and research
at
universities uh International research
centers and branch campuses of us
universities like the one uh that I
teach in in Abu Dhabi uh global izing
curricula of us-based students by adding
modules that require international study
travel or work uh an example of this
is one actually from HBS I don't know if
you can see this but basically it's a
little kind of a flyer that shows how
Global HBS is at the moment apparently
you have onethird foreign students uh
there's a map here which shows eight
Global centers uh for research
California Buenas Iris Istanbul Paris
Mumbai Shanghai among others and
apparently 60% of the cases at HBS are
also Global uh HBS is certainly not
alone hundreds of other American
universities are experiencing the same
thing uh so it's predicted that more and
more International and Global
collaborations are likely to happen in
coming years so in this context what can
Global collaborations Between Women
achieve uh and my in my talk I'm going
to focus on three points the first is
that Global encounters can produce
positive
collaborations the second is that Global
collaborations require authentic
engagement and the third is that Global
collaborations are a form of
power and in addressing these points I'm
going to refer to my own experience and
also some of the research that I've
conducted but I'm not going to provide a
lot of detail on the research because I
was told to sort of stick to a TED Talk
format and really focus on Big Picture
issues that can hopefully facilitate uh
an enrich a dialogue uh among the
group so in terms of the first which is
that Global encounters can produce
positive
collaborations uh going back to 2006 I
had a really unique opportunity to help
set up the first gender and public
policy program in the Arabian Gulf
region uh at the time I was just a young
woman from Saudi Arabia who had received
her PhD from a Western University and I
occupied a really Lial space sort of as
a bicultural person who was able to
straddle multiple worlds um and
establishing a program like this was
really great partially because I was a
closeted feminist at the time uh now
very open um but uh also a really great
opportunity because it was a startup
institution it had good funding and
aspirations to be a regional reference
point uh for work on gender and public
policy in the Arab world so this meant
that we could engage with local and
Global collaborations in research
teaching and programmatic work um and I
wanted to share with you an example uh
we held for we helped supported we
helped support a research uh conference
organized by what is equivalent to a
Ministry of women's Affairs in Dubai
called the Dubai women's establishment
this is a picture that I hope you can
see from that conference one person that
you might recognize sitting in the
middle over here is Kathleen mcin um who
was a speaker at this
conference um we also um organized uh
multi-year teaching collaborations with
uh certain institutions or programs so
this one for example is an image uh of a
group who participated in a leadership
development program called negotiating
for leadership which we designed jointly
with um Iris Bonet from the women in
public policy program uh at the Kennedy
School um it was a really really great
group of women that came from all over
the region uh business women heads of
women's uh sections of Chambers of
Commerce uh entrepreneurs and if you
look closely at the picture you probably
feel a little sorry for this guy because
he was the only guy in the
room but um it was such a fantastic
opportunity because um many of the
people that we invited
uh like Kathleen or Iris were people who
were very thoughtful about engaging with
this uh opportunity they really shared
their knowledge of what they knew but
also were deeply cognizant of the fact
that it was produced in a particular
time and place and for a particular
audience um many of these relationships
I feel very lucky that I'm able to
maintain and I hope will grow over time
but some Global encounters uh are not
that positive uh some of them frankly
are are down downright negative uh we
held for example a leadership
development Roundtable with Scholars and
practitioners um who were working in the
UAE so some of them were from uh the
Emirates but many of them were not they
were foreigners um and what we found is
that the conversation was sort of
deteriorating into a
conversation um about how women in the
UAE were just so much worse off uh than
women in the emancipated and liberal
West um and so attributions of
discrimination were coming down to
simplistic generalizations like well you
know Middle Eastern culture or well this
is how it is with the Muslim religion uh
and often contrasted to the sort of idea
of a um you know a liberal West oh you
know these kinds of things would never
happen back home uh and it was really
curious to me uh as somebody who had
read the work of many Western femin s
who are critical of the forms of
hegemony in their own contexts I found
it fascinating that these encounters
with the Middle East turn the West
discursively into a Bastion of gender
equality and uh Chandra mohania post
Colonial feminist wrote about this kind
of phenomena uh uh in a seminal article
called under Western eyes feminist
scholarship and Colonial discourses and
she here she describes the dynamic and I
just like to share that quote with you
third world women as a group or a
category are automatically and
necessarily defined as religious read
not Progressive family oriented read
traditional legally unsophisticated read
they are still not conscious of their
rights illiterate read ignorant domestic
read backward and sometimes
revolutionary read their country is in a
state of War they must
fight and what this means really is that
without an overdetermined discourse that
creates the third world there would be
no singular privileged first world
without the third world
woman the particular self-representation
of Western women would be
problematic and Chandra mahan's
description is especially true in the
case of uh Middle Eastern or Muslim
women who are often discursively
presented as a counterpart to the
situation of free women in the west and
this actually inspired a collaborative
project with a person in the room that
I'm going to uh mention in a moment
which is sort of tentatively called
feminist
orientalism and what we're trying to do
is really kind of unpack what it
actually means for women in the west to
constantly feel grateful that they're
fairing better than a group of oppressed
women elsewhere and the project combines
postcolonial Theory and social
comparison Theory from psychology to
assess the effect of salient image
of Arab or Muslim women used in downward
comparisons by American women and I'm
not going to go into the details of the
project um but I did want to share kind
of three quick findings from a pretest
that we carried out in a large US
University we found that uh 77% of
female students uh at this University
where we where we ran the pretest
believe that women in the US have it
much better than other women from most
other
countries so basically us women um as a
monolith are
privileged and in a first ranking of
regions 77 women uh percent believe that
women in the Middle East ranked as the
most oppressed while around 80 believe
that North America ranked the least
oppressed so you have this dichotomy
first world versus kind of oppressed
Muslim world and in an open-ended
section where we didn't actually prompt
them uh or give them a region to think
about the majority listed Muslim women
or Middle Eastern women as the category
of women that they hear the most about
in the media and I'm going to give you a
quote just to kind of give you a feel
for some of the responses that we got it
makes me feel proud that I live in
America we have so many more freedoms
than the freedoms that Middle Eastern
women have it helps me keep perspective
about how lucky I am to have this life
that I live so this kind of presence of
this construction of an impressed other
is really key to this feeling of being
grateful and just thankful that what one
has is pretty good relative to what
exists
elsewhere so the point uh is really
because this project is still in its
early stages is that despite the
original Global encounter which was
perhaps far from positive one can
establish a collaboration that takes
advantage of that problematic nature of
the encounter Itself by questioning it
deconstructing it and hopefully moving
forward towards an emancipatory space
that creates new ways of seeing for
everybody the second point that I wanted
to make is that um Global collaborations
require authentic
engagement when I was originally asked
by Robin uh to think about an example of
a positive collaboration with somebody
that I've had that I think of as a
mentor the first person who came to my
mind was Hannah Riley Bulls um she is a
person that I consider a mentor a friend
and an overall absolutely inspiring
person uh I'm sure many of you are
familiar with her work on gender and
negotiation um in a nutshell for those
of you who don't uh she basically looked
at how men and women experience
different social costs when they
negotiate at work and her work shows
basically that women uh versus men incur
a higher penalty when they negotiate
compared to when they don't negotiate
and that this is important because it
has an impact on women's ability to
access leadership positions in
organizations
and through our collaboration over the
last few years we carried out
experimental work in Saudi Arabia and
the United Arab Emirates and we
basically found the same thing that um
in the context of local organizations
the social costs of negotiation for
women or the penalties are higher than
they are for men but what was
interesting is that in the context of
globalization or Global
organizations men tend to suffer a
higher penalty for
negotiation meaning men are also
penalized for negotiation in the context
of global
organizations now we interpret this
essentially as a decline in status so
men's status is relatively lower in
global organizations than in local
organizations because in the global
context they're compared to a neol
neoliberal masculine ideal worker
Benchmark drawing kind of from
sociological Theory uh on globalization
and masculinity
and the reason that I'm giving this
example is that I mentioned this
collaboration not just because I think
it's positive in terms of producing an
outcome of sorts but really because of
the process itself um in working with
Hannah I found that there was a genuine
openness to an authentic engagement with
the region its people and its realities
she really took the time to understand
how people's experiences have shaped
factors that are overlooked or perhaps
not relevant or not well understood
within the US Academy um she engaged
with things like focus groups for
example which are at least for
psychologists not really productive they
don't give you data that you can
immediately publish um but they were
really important to developing the
theoretical um theoretical part of this
work and they gave us a very good feel
for how there were some very deeply held
beliefs that men in the global context
are also discriminated against and are
also um uh are also the uh they they're
the ones that hold disproportionately
negative stereotypes even compared to
women uh and then finally really she was
very patient and creative because having
to deal with an environment that was
lacking in infrastructure for doing
experimental research is not easy is not
like the US context where you have
entire Labs set up you have um you know
post
and market research firms that enable
you to get data quickly this stuff is
expensive it takes time and it can be
very frustrating and it requires a
constant um sort of feedback mechanism
to figure out what we're doing uh that's
actually working other collaborations
that I've been involved in and also that
I've heard of from other
people uh tend to kind of view
International counterparts as
essentially Gatekeepers to data they
just need them to distribute surveys
check the language give minor you know
feedback but actually this kind of
Engagement is highly problematic because
it reinforces unequal Powers power uh
Dynamics between collaborators and it
produces research practices that
actually don't build a long-term
relationships but are more like um quick
wins uh a real collaboration requires
genuine engagement with people's
realities both in terms of the
collaborators but also in terms of the
participants in their research
um and then the third and last point
that I wanted to make uh is that Global
collaboration is power when I conducted
my doctoral work uh uh in Saudi Arabia
on the experience of working women in
Saudi Arabia um many many years ago uh I
was specifically looking at predictors
of their um life satisfaction and their
well-being and I did my fieldwork
through interviews and surveys over the
span of four visits uh to Saudi Arabia
between 2001 and 2004
and uh I introduced my research project
as this is part of a doctoral
dissertation in the department of
experimental psychology at Oxford uh the
goal is to understand the experiences of
working women in Saudi Arabia for purely
research purposes uh all participants
were promised that the information that
they provide uh or that they give about
themselves or their organizations are uh
um Anonymous and will be
confidential um but what I noticed is
that the interviews that I was
conducting across the different
fieldwork visits um were sort of similar
in content but the way that I was being
understood as a researcher was really
evolving and in particular towards the
later fieldwork visits so sort of post
2002 it became clear to me uh that
participants were conscious of how my
research would represent Saudi women
through the West so for example after
interviewing a school teacher and asking
her to introduce me to some of her
colleagues she introduced me as someone
who will help us raise our heads
high and show them and I'm quoting now
in the west that Saudi women work and
they're not like Afghani women in the in
television and while I had certainly not
implied that my project was meant to
showcase the role of saudy women some
participants were clearly attributing
that role to me by virtue of my identity
as somebody who held the same
nationality but was living abroad and
somehow then responsible for the
reputation of the
collective women were were actually
clearly aware an example like this shows
you that women were clearly aware of
what Leela Abul an anthropologist at
Colombia had written in her book do
Muslim women need saving which is that
representations of
Oppression even when they are conducted
in academic or scholarly contexts can be
used to justify military
intervention and so research
participants were well aware that the
data will be ultimately somehow
impacting discourses about them in the
media and in the social World beyond the
scholarly Circle that I thought I was
writing this research for and in my case
because I shared the subjective
positionality with many of the women who
were there perhaps they were more open
in sharing this notion with me even in a
very rudimentary way so I say this in
the context of a conversation about
global collaboration because the notion
of a subjective positionality is
different for collaborators who come
from different
geographies um some of them are likely
to go home and not back to the place
where they collected the data they're
not likely to deal with the consequences
of a research project on a group or a
community of people uh who have to live
with the consequences so given the trend
of going global in Academia
I thought that this is a fantastic time
to engage with and build on some of the
ideas that academic feminists in the
west have championed like
self-reflexivity standpoint Theory and
intersectionality these tools help us
engage with the fundamental nature of
power in global
collaborations so I hope these three
points are helpful uh for fostering a
conversation um on bridging uh the globe
in collaboration orations that Global
encounters can produce positive
collaborations that Global
collaborations require authentic
engagement and that Global
collaborations are after all a form of
power given that you've been staring at
me for the last 15 minutes or so you've
probably also been staring at this
Photograph behind me um so I kind of
feel like I should tell you a little bit
about
it uh this is a photograph um from the
UAE uh it was taken by an marati
photographer called
farim she actually lived in the east
coast of the US for a number of years
she studied at Yale University uh and no
uh Harvard people this is not done on
purpose but um her images are um really
about everyday scenes that she had been
exposed to during her time in the US and
the images that she took may look uh
unremarkable uh seen Through The Eyes of
somebody from the US uh a deli a joint
or in this case uh a street with a
non-descript motel and a few random
cars yet once framed and documented this
encounter becomes an exotic image worthy
of being framed and subject to scrutiny
and an interpretive gaze and Global
collaborations uh can pretty much do the
same thing they can make you really
aware that the most normal looking thing
that you've taken for granted is
actually something worth looking at a
little bit more
closely thank you so much
